Award.AwardTitle: Developing a Vision and Plan for the Northern Utah Geospatial Technology Education Program (NUGTEP)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project addresses the increasing demand for a skilled geospatial technology workforce by government and industry throughout northern Utah. Increasingly, employers require the expertise of geospatial technicians to perform geospatial tasks across a multitude of disciplines. To meet this demand, this project develops the Northern Utah Geospatial Technology Education Program (NUGTEP) to address the region's needs. NUGTEP prepares post-secondary students for successful employment as well as providing additional educational opportunities for individuals already in the geospatial workforce. The foundation for the NUGTEP curriculum is the U.S. Department of Labor Geospatial Technology Competency Model and associated best practices identified by the National ATE Geospatial Technology Center (GeoTech Center). Specific competencies important to the regional Utah geospatial workforce community are also being emphasized in curriculum development. NUGTEP is divided into a two-tier structure. The new Community College First Tier provides students with the opportunity to earn an entry-level certificate or associate degree in Geospatial Technology. The University Second Tier offers an advanced certificate or college minor in Geospatial Analysis. The two-tier model provides students with opportunities to earn credentials in Geospatial Technology, enter the workforce, or if desired, seamlessly advance into the higher level University Tier. The project also provides students internship opportunities that may lead to future employment in the region. Furthermore, NUGTEP serves as a catalyst for future educational outreach efforts in regional secondary schools, and includes the development of summer workshops for secondary teachers who can then introduce their students to the emerging career opportunities available in geospatial technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Weber State University's Small Grants For Institutions New to the ATE Program project successfully created and implemented the Northern Utah Geospatial Technology Education Program (NUGeoTec), with the mission of preparing postsecondary students, university students, and professionals for successful employment/advancement in the geospatial workforce. NuGeoTec (weber.edu/nugeotec) is an interdisciplinary program housed in both the Departments of Earth and Environmental Science (EES), and Geography. The program was launched, and began offering courses during the Fall 2019 semester. Weber State's unique dual-role mission as both a regional community college and large, public, regional comprehensive university serving northern Utah makes this program of great interest to current professionals, postsecondary students, and university students.

NUGeoTec was created using the Logic Model, which is a tool that helps develop proposed project goals, activities and intended outcomes (evalu-ate.org). This approach proved very successful in designing the program plan and completing the tasks required to gain program and curriculum approval and also to launch NUGeoTec. Three major tasks were critical to successfully launching NUGeoTec. First, a Geospatial Advisory Board consisting of geospatial professionals from local, state, and federal governments, private-sector personnel, and higher education professionals was formed to help mold the curriculum. The guidance from the Geospatial Advisory Board ensures students learn the essential geospatial skills expected in todays workforce. Second, a comprehensive needs assessment was conducted by the project evaluator to survey geospatial professionals across northern Utah on both current and future geospatial competencies and skills employers expect from employees. Third, a detailed review and analysis of both the Department of Labor Geospatial Technology Competency Model (GTCM) and geospatial model courses developed by the National Geospatial Technology Center of Excellence ( www.geotechcenter.org/) provided more guidance on the optimal geospatial curriculum. The information collected from the above tasks guided both the revision of current courses and development of new courses to support the programs in NUGeoTec.  A total of 19 geospatial courses support two certificates of proficiency and one minor, all available to postsecondary students, university students, and professionals.

Under NUGeoTec, the new Geospatial Technology Certificate of Proficiency (Geography Department) is designed for postsecondary students or professionals who want to develop the knowledge and skills of a geospatial technician. The revised Geospatial Analysis Certificate of Proficiency and Geospatial Studies Minor (EES Department) are designed for university students and professionals (including geospatial technicians) who want to become geospatial analysts and employ the advanced analysis and innovative modeling skills learned in the program to support their disciplines.

The comprehensive success of the project can be measured in three distinct areas 1.) demonstrating the relevance of a multidisciplinary geospatial education at both the community college and university levels; 2.) the importance of developing quality geospatial curriculum; and 3.) the critical guidance gained through utilizing a Geospatial Advisory Board which led to unanticipated positive outcomes. One major positive outcome was the new joint geospatial science and technology faculty appointment awarded to the EES and Geography Departments to help grow and sustain NUGeoTec. This faculty member brought expertise in the areas of remote sensing and geospatial programming which will help further expand course offerings. A final positive outcome is the new relationship with Farmington High School, where a teacher will offer the introductory geospatial technology course this year. This is a new entry course which will help develop NUGeoTec outreach into secondary schools and form a strong bridge to more advanced geospatial education at Weber State.

 


Last Modified: 09/06/2019
Modified by: Michael W Hernandez
